In this article:
Overview
Creating multiple subject lines and preheaders
How the values are exported
Overview
Multiple Subject Lines and Preheaders allow you to create and manage several subject lines and pre header options directly from your Email Template Overview page within Shaman for both Approved Email and Marketing Email content.
This functionality provides more flexibility when testing or personalising your email content.
Creating multiple Subject lines and Pre headers
From the Overview page, you can now add, edit, or remove multiple Subject lines and Pre header options.
To add more than one option, click "Add option" under the Subject Line or Pre header fields.
Each new entry will appear in a list where you can manage all your options.
Good to know!
If you wish to remove an additional subject line or preheader, simply click the delete (🗑) icon beside it.
How the values are exported
For Approved Email Templates
When syncing an Approved Email template from Shaman to Veeva Vault PromoMats (VVPM) that contains multiple subject lines or preheaders, the entered values will be automatically added to a custom text dropdown token. The token provides a picklist dropdown with the values you entered, allowing the sales reps to select the preferred option before sending the approved email from your CRM environment.
For preheaders, a script is included that reveals the picklist when sending the Email from Veeva CRM, and hides the preheader section again once the Email has been sent out so that the text is not visible in the Email body.

title: HTML Banners in the Visual Builder
body:
In this article:
What is the HTML Banner Builder?
Parts of an HTML Banner
Designing your HTML Banner
Working with Overlays
Prepare for MLR
Exporting your HTML Banner
What is the HTML Banner Builder?
In Shaman, marketers can easily create compliant visual banners (static or animated) with a (scrollable) text overlay, eg for mandatory Important Safety Information (ISI). After approval, the banner can be exported as ready-to-use HTML, aligned with IAB banner guidelines. This package is used to publish the banner across ad networks, like Google Ads.
The HTML Banner Builder is available as an optional feature within the Visual Builder.
Parts of an HTML Banner
An html banner usually has the dimensions of a common banner type like sky scraper, leaderboard or rectangle.
The visual you create or select will represent those size dimensions. When you create a new banner and select the banner subtype, Shaman will propose the official sizes.
The text overlay will be placed on top of this visual. You can set the position. Usually it will be placed at the bottom or on the right side (landscape format).
Please note that this means the visual part of the visual is smaller than the full visual!
​
In the text overlay you can set:
header (text and hyperlinks), will not scroll and always remain visible
body (text, images, hyperlinks), will be scrollable and autoscroll.
Designing your HTML Banner
To get started, open the Visual Builder, select the HTML Banner tab and click "New" like so:
A window will appear prompting you to enter the required details such as brand, name, and language. Once these are completed, you can continue in the Overview tab to finalise the visual component details. Next you can create and edit the visual (Design), manage the text and position of the overlay (Overlay) and start the MLR process (MLR). Once done, the banner is ready to be exported (Export) and published in an Ad network.
The creation and design of a html banner is similar to a visual. For a more detailed overview of creating a new visual component, setting the details in the Overview page, and designing the visuals in the Design stage, please refer to
this article
.
From the Design tab, you will be presented with a dropdown list of the different visual component types, ensure to select the type
HTML Banner
.
In the Start Designing dropdown, you can choose how you want to start:
Blank canvas:
create an HTML Banner “from scratch”
Type of files accepted:
.JPG, .PNG, .HEIC, .TIFF, .SVG, .PDF (single page PDFs)
Start with template
– use an existing HTML banner design template to get started.
If you wish to make the image elements of your HTML Banner animated, ensure to enable the toggle
Animated
before proceeding to the next step.
Good to know!
This means that existing visuals in Shaman, both static and animated, can be reused as HTML banner. You have 2 options to reuse:
Use an existing visual template
Duplicate a visual and change type to: HTML Banner
Working with Overlays
The overlay is an HTML layer containing text, links, and images, managed directly in Shaman. Once created, an overlay is saved in a reusable library (brand-specific if selected), allowing teams to quickly apply it across multiple banners. This not only saves time but also ensures consistency and compliance.
In the Text overlay card, you can either create a new text overlay or select an existing one:
Create a new text overlay
When creating a new overlay, add:
Header section
This section is non-scrollable, it will stick at the top of the scrollable text. So make sure to keep the text short. You can use rich text editor options to add hyperlinks, change color, add superscript.
Body section
This section is scrollable, it will auto scroll and scrollable by viewer. You can add full ISI text (limit 5000 chars).  You can use rich text editor options to add hyperlinks, add bullets, change color, add superscript. You can also add images (from the visual library) in line in the text. Once added, you can resize images in the text.
NB: Size limits (300kb or even 200kb) is a big challenge when creating banners. If you want to insert images, you should resize those images before uploading (or change file size in the Shaman image editor) and only use images as small as possible. Ideally, they are so small you don't need to resize them in the Body.
When you make changes to the overlay, you can immediately preview the results below in the Preview card.
Once done, you can save the Text overlay and reuse in other banners.
When you create the MLR document (PDF), the Text overlay will be added for review.
When the text is brand specific, you should restrict the use of the overlay for a specific brand by enabling the "Brand related" toggle. In that case, the Text Overlay will only appear in the list of Text Overlays when working on HTML banners of the same brand.
Good to know!
When you change a Text Overlay, these changes will apply for all banners where the Text overlay is used (see column 'Where Used' to find these banners). To apply this change, these other banners need to be re-exported.
Once the Text overlay is set, you return to the banner overlay. Below in the
Configure Overlay
section, you can set the following configurations:
Position of overlay
- Determines where do you want to have the overlay (bottom, left, right, top)
Size overlay
- Defines the pixel dimensions of the overlay and how much space it occupies within the design
Opacity overlay background -
Allows you to set a percentage of opacity for the text section of your overlay
Target url -
You can add a URL where the user will be directed to when they click on the HTML banner (visual area - the clicks in the text overlay can be set using hyperlinks).
From the
Preview
section, you can view your HTML banner exactly as it will appear once published. Any changes you make in the design or overlay configuration will be reflected here in real time, allowing you to check that the layout, text, and visuals appear as intended.
Start the MLR process
When the banner visual and overlay are ready, you can prepare for the MLR process. Go to the MLR tab, where you can sync the content to Veeva Vault, either by creating a new MLR document in Vault with rendition in Shaman, or link to an existing placeholder and sync the rendition file (PDF). When generating the HTML banner rendition PDF, Shaman will add:
Overlay on top of the visual; showing the final viewable result
If animated, Shaman will generate a frame per scene, incl the overlay
Additional page in PDF containing the full Body section of the overlay, including clickable links.
From this section, you can also export your HTML banner as a PDF file. In that case, these PDF additions are optional:
This article
provides detailed, step-by-step instructions for the MLR process and exporting your visual component.
Exporting your HTML Banner
When the banner is MLR reviewed and approved, you can proceed to the Export tab.
Here, you can download the HTML package of the banner (zip), including:
index.html
\assets
image visual (png or gif)
other images used in the body section
It is important that you check the size of the .zip before you send it to the publishing platform. Most platforms have a size limitation, the official AIB guidelines is 300kb.
Especially when you have an animated banner, this can be challenging. In that case make sure you set lowest export settings:
Other tips to reduce gif file size:
remove text and shape animations
remove transitions
reduce duration
You can also refer to
this article
for more information on creating animated visuals in Shaman.

Introducing Veeva Vault Document Owner
This function will help to save you time and streamline your workflow, we’ve added a handy new option that allows you to manually select a Veeva document owner in Shaman during export, giving the document owner full control over the document workflow in Veeva Vault.

Whether you are exporting an email template, an email fragment or a CLM presentation, you will notice a field named
Document Owner in Veeva Vault

title: Content review in Shaman
description: Take a closer look at how Content Review can help you save time and syncs
body:
In this article:
What is Content Review in Shaman?
How does Content Review work?
Taking a look at Content Review in action
What is Content Review in Shaman?
Content review is a new feature in Shaman which makes the creation of compliant and effective email content in Shaman even easier.
You might already be familiar with “Audit” in Shaman, which performed a similar review of email content at the Design stage. Content Review offers an easier to use UI (than Audit),  effortlessly integrating with your existing Design process, as well as even more useful functionalities than before.
We hope that by bringing these details to your attention during the content creation process (rather than in the testing process), Content Review will save you time and syncs.
Content Review can be tailored specifically to your account requirements, so get in touch with your dedicated Customer Success manager to find out how your content creation team can start benefiting from this great new feature.
How does Content Review work?
Content Review scans the content of your email design, and based on which Critical and Warning options you have chosen (as part of your account configuration), you might see:
Critical:
Observations which must be “resolved” before syncing to Veeva Vault:
Unsubscribe link missing: This notification will show if there is no URL/ Veeva token which offers readers the option to “Unsubscribe” from the email campaign
Veeva tokens: You will be notified if a Veeva token is incomplete or incorrectly completed.
​​Button link missing: This notification will show there is no Action (eg. open a URL, send an email, download a Veeva hosted document) added to a button.
Hyper text link is missing: You will be notified if there is no URL/ Veeva token populated in a hyperlink created for text in an email.
Warning suggestions:
You can decide to not address the Warning suggestions and sync content to Veeva Vault with open Warning notifications. But we highly recommend you review the comments to avoid unnecessary edits or future syncs.
Disclaimer link missing: A warning notification will appear if there is no URL link/ Veeva token populated for a Disclaimer
SmPC/PI link missing: You will be notified if there is no URL link/ Veeva token populated for a SmPC/ PI document.
Approval number missing: A warning notification will appear if there is no approval number added to your Email Design. (Approval number can normally be found within the MLR approval email/ notification from your internal approval system).
Privacy policy link missing: This warning notification will appear if there is no URL populated in the Privacy policy of this email campaign.
No button found: You will be notified if there is no button/ call to action in your Email Design.
No salutation tokens found: Salutation tokens are any Veeva tokens which address the HCP directly, for example #{{Account.Name}}, #{{accTitle}},#{{accFname}} or #{{accLname}}. A warning notification will appear if there are no such Veeva tokens in your Email Design.
No sender tokens found: Sender tokens are any Veeva tokens which contain details about the Sender (sales team/ end user) of the Email. For example, #{{userEmailAddress}}, #{{userName}} or #{{userPhoto}}
Consider using a picklist:
If a Veeva custom picklist token is used which does not contain options (for example {​{​customText[options]}}, a warning notification will appear.
Image alt text is missing: Alternative text can be added to images uploaded to email content in Shaman which will show if the images in the email are not successfully downloaded when the HCP opens the email. You will receive a Warning notification if there is no alternative text added to an image.
Proofread*:
Proofread scans the text copy within your email design and alerts you to any formatting, spelling or grammatical errors, as well as suggestions which make your key message clearer or more consistent with the rest of the copy in your email.
* - Proofread is available in Content review as part of the AI package. Reach out to your dedicated Customer Success Manager to find out more details.
Taking a look at Content Review in action
When working on the design of an email template or fragment, on the right hand side of the email canvas you will see the button “Content Review”.
You can click on any of the corresponding “Critical”, “Proofread” or “Warning” to view the notifications for each category.
Simply click on the notification to view further details about which part of the email content needs to be reviewed.
In the case of “Proofread” notifications, you can choose to “Apply” the suggestion directly to your email content. For example, take a look at this suggestion which states the format of the time which the event begins is incorrect. We can “Apply” the suggestion, or choose to “Ignore” it.
In the case of “Warning” notifications, you can choose to “Ignore” them to remove the warning message from the Content Review panel.

What is Shaman Hub?
How can I copy Marketing Email content from Shaman Hub?
How can I contribute to Shaman Hub?
What is Shaman Hub?
With Shaman Hub, sharing Marketing Email content from a global to local level, or a local to local level has never been easier (or quicker!).
Shaman Hub for Marketing Email will only show you content which has an MLR document attached, meaning that non compliant content is kept safely out of reach.
In this article we will take a closer look at how you can search for Marketing Email content in Shaman Hub, how you can save it to your local list of Marketing Email content to personalize as you please and very importantly - how you can share your best Marketing Email content to Shaman Hub to inspire your colleagues and contribute to the overall success of your organization!
How can I copy Marketing Email content from Shaman Hub?
After logging into Shaman, click “Marketing Email” in your builder dashboard.
From the Marketing Email builder overview, click the “Shaman Hub” tab.
When you arrive at your hub page, you will see some search filters on the left hand side, a list of content that has already been shared on your hub, as well as a search bar at the top of your screen to type keywords to help you find the right content for you. Let's take a closer look.
Search filters on the left:
Source:
Global and local - You can choose to search for content that has been created at a global, or local level by clicking to select the corresponding filter.
Original Brand:
Perhaps you are working on a specific brand team, and would like to find content relating to this specific brand. If so, this is the search filter for you.
Original language:
you can search for content which has been created in your local language or in other languages.
Type:
you can search for email templates, or dynamic content blocks.
Country of origin:
you can search for content created by a specific country using this filter.
Good to know!
If you do not see a value in the list of filters, eg. a brand or a country, it is most likely that content for this brand or country has not yet been shared on the hub, but don´t hesitate to contact your Shaman Customer Success Manager or the Shaman Support Team (support@getshaman.com) for more information.
Search bar at the top: Simply start typing any keywords to find content relevant to your email campaign.
List of content shared on the hub: Here you can see all content currently available on your hub, sorted based on relevancy. Let’s take a look at the information you can see in this email overview.
Title:
The title of the Marketing email content
Local or Global:
Whether it has been created at a global or local level.
Subject line:
(in case of email templates)
Summary:
An AI generated summary of the contents of the email content (in English)
Created by:
The name and franchise of the colleague who created this content
Likes:
How many people have “liked” the email content
Duplicates:
How many people have duplicated the content to their local work area
Date added:
The date the content was added
Expiry date:
The date this content will expire (in Shaman Hub)

“Tags” help you manage and organize CLM presentation content in Shaman.
You can create a tag that is specific to a project, team, or even team member, and then add this tag to each CLM presentation to easily manage all content related to that tag.
Tags are created, managed, and visible only within Shaman, they will not show in Veeva Vault or Veeva CRM.
Good to know!
If you also have the Shaman email builder active in your account, you can create and add “Global” tags, which will be available to use for both email and CLM presentation content.

Tags in the CLM presentation builder are created through the CLM presentation overview page.
Select any one of the small square boxes to the left of the CLM presentations.
To create a new tag, click “Manage tags”, then click the green “New” button in the top right corner.
You will now see that a new blank tag has been added to your list of tags in the CLM presentation builder. To add a name to your tag, simply begin typing in the blank space beneath the name field. You can also update the color of your tag, by selecting from the options available in the dropdown list.
You can also decide which type of content this tag should be available for: CLM presentation, or All content (Global). Selecting the "CLM presentation" tag will make this tag available for use only for CLM presentation content, and selecting the "All content (Global)" tag will be available for use in the email builder, and the CLM presentation builder.
Once you are happy with the details you have added to your tag, click "save" using the button next to the newly created tag. Then click "back to overview" to return to the CLM presentation overview page, and keep reading to find out how to assign your recently created tag to CLM presentation content!
How to add a tag to CLM presentations
There are two ways that you can add tags to CLM presentations, from the overview of CLM presentations, or from the overview page of a specific CLM presentation.
From the overview of CLM presentations page:
Select the CLM presentations that you wish to add tags to (by clicking the small square boxes to the left of the CLM presentations.
At the top of the list of CLM presentation content, type the name of the tag you wish to assign into the free text field “Add tags”. A dropdown list will then appear with a list of all the available tags in your account. Simply click to select the tag(s) you wish to add. When you have finished selecting tags, click the “Add” button on the right-hand side of the screen.
You will then see that the CLM presentation(s) selected has now been assigned the chosen tags.
How to remove tags from CLM presentation content
To remove a tag from a CLM presentation, simply click the “x” delete icon and the tag will be removed.
To remove a tag completely from your account, first, make sure it is not being used (as you will not be able to delete it). Select any one of the small square boxes to the left of the CLM presentations and then click “Manage tags”.
Then, click “Delete” next to the tag you wish to delete.

Introduction to working with icons
Icons visually communicate ideas in a simple and straightforward way, making them the perfect companion to text in email content. Icons can also boost your brand identity, and guide your reader towards the most important content in your email.
So we are delighted to let you know that we have added a section in the Visual library just for icons in Shaman! Official brand icons can be added in bulk by the Shaman team and then can be seamlessly made available to your content teams in branded colors.
If you would like to learn more about how to activate the Icon library in your Shaman account, please reach out to your dedicated Customer Success Manager.
If the Icon library is already active in your account, carry on reading to find out how you can easily add icons to your email content.
How to add icons to email content
Let´s imagine that you have created a new email fragment or template, have completed the email details, and are now in the HTML editor ready to add elements to your email fragment or template. (If you need to revise any of these steps,
check out this article here).
From the menus on the right-hand side, select the content menu. Find the image icon in the content menu, and simply drag and drop that icon onto your email canvas.
You will notice that a grey placeholder image has been added to the email canvas. To add an icon to the email canvas instead, click the “Visual library” button from the menu on the left-hand side.
You will then be redirected to the visual library, where you will see the tab “Icons” available to select.
Here you will find a list of icons supplied by your brand lead to Shaman. You can browse through the list of icons, or you can use the search bar or time filters to find the icon you are looking for:
To select an icon to add to your canvas, simply click the selection circle which will reveal the “Add” button in the top right hand corner:
Once you have clicked “Add”, you will see a list of pre-added brand colours available to select. Choose the colour which you would like to assign to the icon.
You will then be redirected back to the email canvas, where the icon will be added to the email canvas in the selected brand color.
Using the menu on the right-hand side, you can then define additional optional settings for the image.
Auto Width: This setting is a toggle that sets an image automatically to fit the width of your email content. To set the width of an image manually, you can disable the auto width toggle and use the slider to resize your image bigger or smaller.
Align: This setting allows you to define the alignment of your image in relation to your email content by selecting from the left, center, right, or full alignment icons.
Alternate Text: Alternative Text is meant to convey the “why” of the image as it relates to the content of a document or webpage. It also displays on the page if the image fails to load.
If you wish to have alternative text for your image, you can add it to this field simply by typing directly into the box available.
Action: Here you can add an action such as if the email recipient clicks on the image, a specific webpage will be opened. There are several options to choose from in the dropdown menu on the right-hand side (which shows “Open Website” as a default action).
Open website
Send email
Call phone number
Send SMS
Depending on which option you choose, additional fields will be displayed to further personalize the action. For example, if you choose the “Open Website” option, you will need to populate the URL link in the field provided. You can also define whether a new tab is opened, or if the webpage is viewed on the same tab in the reader's browser.
Top tip!
When using the “Open website” option, we always recommend you copy the URL directly from the browser before pasting it in this URL field to avoid any typos or incorrect links.
Container Padding: Padding can be used to perfectly position images within the body of your email content. You can choose to add the same padding to all sides by maintaining the “All sides” toggle enabled. Or, you can disable this toggle to manually configure the padding size for each side of the image. You can use the plus and minus icons to increase or decrease the padding, or you can type a numerical value directly into the padding box.
Hide on Desktop: When this toggle is enabled, the image will not be displayed when viewing the email on a desktop computer or laptop, it will only be viewable on a mobile view.
Good to know!
We highly recommend you pay attention to how your email content looks on both mobile and desktop views. To learn more great tips when creating email content compatible with mobile and desktop views, take a look at
this article here.
How to update an existing icon with a new icon
If you want to change an icon that has already been added to the email canvas, select the icon by clicking on it. Then, from the menu on the left-hand side, click the “Visual library” button.
You will be redirected back to the Visual library where you can select a different icon following the same steps as previously stated.
You will then be redirected back to the email canvas, where the selected icon will be added to the email canvas.
How to delete or duplicate icons
To delete an icon, simply click the icon to select it. You will then notice two icons - a bin icon to delete the image, and a copy icon to duplicate it.
Depending on which you wish to do, simply click the icon, and your image will either be deleted or duplicated.

title: New: Animated visual!
description: How to create GIFs in the Visual builder
body:
In this article:
Introduction
How to create an Animated visual in Shaman
Scenes
Locking
Audio
Animation
Export visual component as a PDF (for MLR)
Export visual component to Shaman visual library, or as a GIF file to your computer
Introduction
You can now create animated visual components (commonly known as GIFs) in the Shaman Visual builder! GIFs are a great way of engaging your audience by maximizing the potential of your visual content.
Before we get started:
We highly recommend that you keep GIFs as light in size as possible, as heavy visual files will cause difficulties for approved email content. The more scenes and animations you add to a visual file, the heavier/ larger the file will be.
If you have any doubts about creating a new visual component in Shaman, you can take a look at
this article
.
How to create an Animated visual in Shaman
Once you have created a new visual component, set the obligatory information such as brand or name, and clicked the “Design” tab  and selected the “Type” of visual component you are creating, you will see the “Animated” field appear beneath “Subtype”.
Good to know!
Currently Shaman supports a maximum file size of 480k pixels (800*600).
Once you have selected a “Subtype”, you can simply click the “Animated” checkbox and then click “Create canvas”
You will then be redirected to the visual builder canvas. Once you have added some visual content to the canvas, you will see the following options on the right hand side:
Scenes: If you wish to add more than one visual to the Animated GIF, you can add different “scenes” which hold the different images
Locking: Here you can configure “locking” to prevent parts of the visual component from being edited.
Audio: Please do not add any audio files to visual components as they are not currently supported in Shaman. Any audio files added to Animated visuals will be removed when the visual elements are added to the email builder.
Animation: Select an animation effect for each scene in your visual component
Across the bottom of the email canvas you will see some additional options for the animation element of the GIF:
Play scene: Click play to view the animations within the current scene you are viewing
Play all: Click play to preview the animations across all scenes created
Plus icon: Shortcut to create a new scene
Copy icon: Shortcut to duplicate a scene
Bin icon: Shortcut to delete a scene
Navigation arrows: Shortcut to navigate between scenes
Now that you are familiar with the GIF canvas, we will take a look at each of the following menus in more detail:
Scenes
Locking
Animation
Scenes
As mentioned previously, you can add different “scenes” to an animated file which hold different images within the GIF. At any stage in the scene creation process you can add other text, images or shapes and add animation effects as desired
(see the Animation section here
).
To add a new scene, simply click the “Add” button in the menu on the right hand side.
To increase or decrease the duration of a scene, use the arrows next to the timings under the scene preview thumbnail in the menu on the right hand side.
When you click the three dots under the scene preview, you will see the following additional options:
Add Scene name: You can add a name to your scene to help keep track of the different scenes within your animated GIF.
Clone: Click here to duplicate the scene
Split into scene slides: You can split a scene into further “child” scenes, allowing you to add animation effects between the same visual (applied to different scenes).
Delete: Click here to delete a scene.
Convert to layout: Click here to convert the scene to a layout.
Good to know!
Layouts work in a similar way to a design template in that you can create a layout, and then create new scenes using this layout.
Locking
The “locking” tool (when used in a design template) ensures that obligatory visual (eg. a brand logo) or written information (eg. legal disclaimers, dosing information, etc) which should not be updated or edited is out of bounds for anyone but the creator of the template.
What elements can I lock in Shaman?
Text
Images (Media)
Shapes
Background
Audio
As mentioned previously in this article: Please do not add any audio files to visual components as they are not currently supported in Shaman. Any audio files added to Animated visuals will be removed when the visual elements are added to the email builder.
Animation
Using the animation tab, a variety of animations can be applied to the “intro” or “outro” of a selected scene, or all scenes.
“Intro” refers to the animation that can be applied to the beginning or arrival of the content element to the scene, whereas the “outro” refers to the animation that can be applied to the ending or exit of the content element from a scene.
The options available are:
None: Select this option to not apply any animation to your visual element.
Fade
Pan
Rise
Pop
Unite
Tumble
Scale
Trample
Simply click an option to select it. Once you have selected an animation option, you will see two further options:
Delay: The element(s) will not be visible until this delay has elapsed, at which point the animation will play
Duration: This refers to how long the animation will take to complete.
Good to know!
If the delay and duration together exceed the total duration of the scene, a warning message will appear advising you to adjust either delay, duration of animation or duration of the scene.
You see in the menu on the right hand side a button to “Apply to all elements”. This will apply the chosen animation to all content elements within the scene (if you have more than one content element on the canvas).
Once you are happy with the Animated visual created, the next step is to export or publish the animated visual using the “Export” page.
Export visual component as a PDF (for MLR)
From the “MLR” tab you can export a PDF document to arrive in your email inbox, or use the “Download” option to download the PDF directly to your computer.
Export visual component to Shaman visual library, or as a GIF file to your computer
From the design canvas, click the “Export” tab to be directed to the list of Export options in Shaman.
The first section we should review contains the “Animated gif details”, where we need to set:
Frames per second: Here you can set the animation smoothness and file size. The higher the frames per second, the higher the animation smoothness (but also higher the file size). In general, we suggest 5 FPS or lower to keep file size manageable, especially for banners with limits. We recommend you to use higher FPS only if you are using animation effects.
Quality: The quality is a balance between the quality of the visual and the file size. Medium is usually sufficient quality to keep the file size within size limits, whilst maintaining a good standard of image quality. You can adjust the quality based on the animation detail.
Loop: Determines whether the animation repeats. When enabled, the animation will continuously loop. When disabled, it will play once and stop at the final frame.
Next you can decide whether you wish to share the Animated Visual to your internal Hub (if relevant!).
To export your Animated visual to the Shaman library, you can click the “Export” button, or alternatively click “Send to Email” or “Download” to receive the GIF file to your inbox, or to your computer.
Add the GIF to your email
To add the GIF to your email, start by adding the image placeholder to the body of your email, then open the "Visual Library".
In the Visual Library, click on the GIF you exported from the Visual Builder.
The GIF will immediately be added to the email body.
If you have any questions or face any challenges, please reach out to our Support Team using the chat bubble on the bottom right corner, or email us at
support@getshaman.com
.

In this article:
What is Shaman Hub for Visual Components?
Where can I find Shaman Hub for Visual Components?
How does it work?

What is Shaman Hub for Visual Components?
Shaman Hub is available for each of our content builders, allowing the sharing of content from a global to local level, or a local to local level in a matter of clicks!
In this article we will take a closer look at how you can search for visual content in Shaman Hub, how you can save it to your local list of visual content to personalize and very importantly - how you can share your best visual content to Shaman Hub to inspire your colleagues and contribute to the overall success of your organization!
Where can I find Shaman Hub for Visual components?
After logging into Shaman, click “Visuals” in your builder dashboard.
From the Visual builder overview, click the “Shaman Hub” tab.
Good to know!
Your hub name is unique to your organization, so in your account you will see “your organization name - Hub”.
When you arrive at your hub page, you will see some search filters on the left hand side, a list of content that has already been shared on your hub, as well as a search bar at the top of your screen to type keywords to help you find the right content for you. Let's take a closer look.
You can find the following search filters on the left:
Source: Global and local - You can choose to search for content that has been created at a global, or local level by clicking to select the corresponding filter.
Brand: Perhaps you are working on a specific brand team, and would like to find content relating to this specific brand. If so, this is the search filter for you.
Original language: you can search for content which has been created in your local language or in other languages.
Country: you can search for content created by a specific country using this filter.
Type: You can use the filters “Email visual”, “Banner”, etc to find a specific type of visual content
Good to know!
If you do not see a value in the list of filters, eg. a brand or a country, it is most likely that content for this brand or country has not yet been shared on the hub, but don´t hesitate to contact your Shaman Customer Success Manager or the Shaman Support Team (support@getshaman.com) for more information.
Search bar at the top: Simply start typing any keywords to find relevant visual content.
List of content shared on the hub: Here you can see all content currently available on your hub, sorted based on relevancy. Let’s take a look at the information you can see in this email overview.
Title: The title of the visual component
Local or Global: Whether it has been created at a global or local level.
Summary: An AI generated summary of the contents of the visual content (in English)
Created by: The name and franchise of the colleague who created this content
Likes: How many people have “liked” the visual content
Duplicates: How many people have duplicated the content to their local work area
Date added: The date the content was added
Expiry date: The date this content will expire (in Shaman Hub)
How does it work?
To take a closer look at a visual component presented in the Hub for visual builder overview, simply click anywhere within the visual component details shown.
You will be redirected to a page where you can preview the visual content and review the details before duplicating it.
On the right hand side you will see a “Duplicate visual component” section. If you like what you see in the preview, you can complete the details in the “Update details and duplicate to your account” section.
Account: Select the account where you wish to copy this visual content to.
Name: Add a new name or title to your visual content
Brand: You can choose to keep the inherited brand assigned to your visual content, or you can click “Update” to change it to a different brand.
Language: Select the language you wish to use in your visual content. If it´s different from the language in the original content, don´t worry we´ve got you! Shaman will automatically translate this to the language you have selected.
Once you have set these details, click “Duplicate”.
You will be redirected to the visual component overview page which you are likely to be very familiar with by now. Click “Design” to start personalizing the visual content you have copied.
Once in the Design section, you can start adding new elements to the visual component or update the existing content as you wish.
Good to know!
As part of the Brand design system implemented by Shaman, any new content elements added by you will inherit your brand identity colours, fonts and padding requirements.
If you select another language in the duplication step, Shaman will automatically translate the Visual component to the selected language, using AI translation. Make sure that the translation result is reviewed carefully.
If you have any doubts and want to check the original text, simply click “Show original visual component”.
To review any steps about adding content to your visual component,
please click here
, or how to export your visual component from Shaman,
please click here.
How can I contribute to Shaman Hub?
Sharing your visual content on Shaman Hub could not be easier.
Once you are ready to export your content to the Shaman visual library, you just need to select the "Export" tab of the Visual component.
At the top of your export options, you will see the following criteria that you can select to share with your colleagues, based on:
Brand: You can choose to only share with colleagues working with the same brand as you
Countries: You can choose to only share content with specific countries
Therapeutic Area: You can choose to only share content with users working in similar therapeutic area to you, for example: Neurology, Cardiology, etc.
And importantly: “Share with other users” toggle. This needs to be enabled to share content with your colleagues.
If you do not want to share your visual content to Shaman Hub, be sure to deactivate this toggle to prevent your visual component from being shared.
On clicking export, your content will also be shared to your Shaman Hub.
If you have any questions or doubts about Shaman Hub, please get in touch with your dedicated Customer Success manager or the support team (using the green chat bubble or contacting us at support@getshaman.com).

title: Best practices when creating email content for Outlook
description: Take a look at the Shaman teams top tips when creating email content in Outlook
body:
In this article:
Introduction
Background images
Web fonts and web safe fonts
Buttons populated with an incomplete URL or Veeva token (outlook.com)
Animated GIFs
Working with padding and images
Introduction
At Shaman, we help our users to create and test email content for a range of email inbox providers (eg. Apple mail, Gmail or Outlook) on a daily basis. We have learnt a lot of handy tips when working with different email clients over time, but the one email client provider that we receive the most questions about is: Outlook.
Perhaps you have experienced a heading not rendering as expected when testing in Outlook, or some images which are showing with a different alignment than the one you designed? In which case, this article is for you!
We would like to thank our users who have inspired this article and we sincerely hope that this list of best practices and tips is helpful.
Background images
In Outlook, background images can cause other content elements which are placed in the same row to render unexpectedly.
Let´s take a look at an example. Here you can see a background image:
With two images placed on top (using the Image element in the content menu):
Gmail preview:

Outlook preview:
Recommendation/ solution:
Create a single image which layers the background image with the other content elements on top:
Gmail preview:
Apple mail preview:
Outlook preview:
Consider updating the email design without using a background image (for example, splitting the background image into two columns:
Gmail preview:
Apple mail preview:
Outlook preview:
Web fonts and web safe fonts
Let´s take a quick look at what are web fonts, and web safe fonts
Web safe fonts: Prompt the web browser to retrieve the font from the pre installed fonts on your computer. Web safe fonts (as the name suggests!) are safe to use, as it is very likely the person reading the email will have them.
Examples: Arial, Helvetica, Tahoma, Times New Roman.
On the contrary, web fonts are retrieved from a server hosted by an external source (or by your own server). The variety of fonts is much greater, but - they are only supported in a limited number of email clients. And yes you have guessed it, Outlook is not one of the email clients which supports web fonts.
Examples: Poppins, Open Sans, Roboto, Montserrat
So what happens in Shaman if you use a web font in Shaman, but the end user views the email content in Outlook? In Shaman, your account fonts are configured to always have a web safe back-up font, for any web font selected. For example, font selected: Montserrat, back up font: Arial.
You can´t see this “back up” font in the email editor, but we can see it is there, in these litmus previews that in Outlook (an email provider which does not support web fonts), the text is rendered using Arial:
Outlook preview:
In apple mail preview:
Recommendation/ Solution:
Make sure that any fonts you are choosing (web safe fonts or web fonts) are looking good across a range of email clients. If you have any doubts about the font configuration in your account, please reach out to
support@getshaman.com
.
Buttons populated with an incomplete URL or Veeva token (outlook.com)
Another situation we have noticed when using Outlook.com is that when a button is populated with an incomplete URL, or with a token which is being tested in Shaman (not from Veeva CRM), the button disappears, and only the token is displayed (or in the case of an incomplete URL, nothing at all).
When testing the email, the Veeva or Marketing Cloud tokens will not be recognised as a valid URL, and may cause rendering issues. When the Email is sent out from Veeva CRM or Salesforce Marketing Cloud, the tokens are replaced by valid link URL's and the button should render correctly. We always recommend final testing in a sandbox environment before making email content available in production.
Veeva token (for Veeva hosted document in this case) in Shaman:
Outlook.com preview:
Apple mail preview:
Incomplete URL in Shaman:
Outlook.com preview:
Animated GIFs
Some Outlook desktop clients do not support
animated GIFs
. Outlook 2016 and Outlook 2019
do
support GIFs now, but other versions do not. So, check your version of Outlook, first!
Working with padding and images
Outlook removes any padding to images when they are added to the column rather than the container padding of the image itself.
Let´s take a look at this example, where we have three equally sized columns, containing an equally sized image in a row, with 10 px padding added to each column:
This is how the images render in:
Apple mail preview:
Gmail preview:
Outlook preview:
We can see that not only are the images rendering without the added padded (see how they are wider than the grey text above in the Outlook preview), but also the top of the images are being cropped:
Recommendation/ solution:
Add the padding to the "General" - "Container Padding" which appears when selecting the image itself:
To resolve the top part of the image being cropped, reduce the size of the image slightly:
Outlook preview after changes are made:
It is incredibly important to ensure every person receiving your email will receive the content as you designed it, but you may be surprised to know that according to a Litmus analytics report from October 2024
https://www.litmus.com/email-client-market-share
, 4.18% of people view their email content using Outlook.
If you have any other examples or thoughts about creating email content for Outlook, please get in touch with us

body:
What is the difference between the different types, or is “type” just to organize the content in Shaman? Are types customisable per account?
Types and subtypes are customizable per account, and provide like a base canvas (say email banner might be 600x350px or something, suitable for the use)
What is subtype? Is this customisable per account?
Yes! The subtype options available will depend on which type has been selected. You can think of type and subtype as hierarchical, with the “type” selected deciding which relevant subtypes should be available for selection. For example, if the type “banner” is selected, the subtypes available will be more specific examples of banners eg. medium rectangle or leaderboard.
Depending which subtype you select, the corresponding default dimensions for the subtype will appear underneath. These fields are completely editable, so you can continue with the predefined default dimensions, or update them to custom values.
What file formats are accepted?
Blank canvas: create a visual component “from scratch”
Type of files accepted:
.JPG, .PNG, .HEIC, .TIFF, .SVG, .PDF (single page PDFs)
Import design: upload a PDF file (with one page or multiple pages) to import into the visual builder
Type of files accepted:
.PDF - single page and multipage
.JPG, .PNG, .HEIC, .TIFF, .SVG, .PDF (single page PDFs)
Start with a template: You can choose to create a visual component from an existing template
Type of files accepted:
.JPG, .PNG, .HEIC, .TIFF, .SVG, .PDF (single page PDFs)
What is the difference between importing a design and starting from scratch?
You can choose the “Import Design” option to upload a PDF and turn it into editable items, or start from scratch. Within the visual builder, you can also upload images, but not use them as a “base” as per the “Import Design” option.
Why is it necessary to add a language to an image?
In case the image contains text, for any future translation and duplication needs.
Once I have set the dimensions of a visual component, it is not possible to update the component dimensions?
Yes it is! In the design step, go to “Background” and you can set the size there
Where can I download a PDF of my visual component?
Navigate to the MLR tab in your visual component to find the options to download or export a PDF.
Where can I download a PNG or JPG of my visual component?
Navigate to the export tab in your visual component to find the options to download or export a PDF, PNG, or JPG.
Where can I export the visual component to the image library in Shaman email builders?
Navigate to the export tab in your visual component to find the option to "Export" the visual component to the image library in Shaman email builders.
How can I update a visual component in the image library in Shaman email builders?
Navigate to the export tab of your visual component to find the option to "Export again". After clicking this option, the updated visual component will then be published to the image library in Shaman email builders.
Good to know!
If you have any doubts about which versions were published on which date, you can take a look at the “Design Change History” on the Visual Component Overview page. You will notice that any previous live version has been moved to “Superseded”, meaning that it has been superseded by the latest published version.
Do you have a question that is not on this list? Please contact the support team using the green chat bubble in your account, or via email (
support@getshaman.com
).

From the export tab within the Visual component, in the “Export visual component” section select PNG, PDF or JPG from the File format options available.
Simply click:

Download: to download the visual component created directly to your computer.
Publishing to the Shaman email image library
Simply click the “Publish” button in the export tab to set your visual component live within the image library in Shaman email builders.
A progress screen will appear showing you the sync progress.
Once the sync is complete, you will see that the image is now Live (available for use), as well as the date of the Last sync.
Good to know!
If you want to set the image back to draft, you can do so by using the “Set back to draft” option.
If you have Hub for Visual components enabled in your account, you will also have the option to share the images to Hub on the export page.
If you wish to share the visual component to Hub, keep the "Share content" toggle enabled. You will also need to complete the following obligatory fields before doing so:
Visual component summary: a brief description of what the visual component is about to ensure that the image can be easily found by your colleagues using keyword searches.
Hub expiry date: The visual component will be available to use in Shaman until the specified expiry date.
Then, click Publish to share the content to Hub and also Shaman image libraries.
If you do not wish to share the visual component to Hub - simply disable the toggle "Share content", followed by the "Publish" button.

How to add a new background to a visual component
From the menu on the left hand side, select the “background” icon by clicking on it.
You will then see the following options available when working with backgrounds:
Color: add a solid color to the background
Photo: add a photo as background
Size: Amend the size of your background
Adding a color background
After clicking the “Color” option, you will see a small color sample which can be clicked to reveal the color picker tool.
You can either select the background fill color using a hex code, the color picker tool or one of the predefined brand colors already added to your account.
Adding a photo as a background
Moving onto the “photo” option. To add a photo as the background to a visual component, click “Photo” option to reveal a series of additional options:
Upload: Select this option to upload an image from your computer
Photos: Select this option to browse existing images found in your visual components
Once you have selected the image you wish to set as your background, you will see an option to scale the image before it is set as the background:
